channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Venice Is Saved! Woe Is Venice.
item.description: Produced by Mona Boshnaq
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Emma Bubola and Laetitia Vancon

item.title: China Draws Lessons From Russia’s Missteps in Ukraine
item.description: With an eye on a possible conflict over Taiwan, analysts have scrutinized the war for insights ranging from the importance of supply lines to the power of nuclear threats.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: New recruits of the People’s Liberation Army at a send-off ceremony in eastern China. Experts studying Russia’s war have said that Moscow’s manpower shortfall shows that China needed to keep its ground forces strong.

item.title: Pope Francis Quips He’s ‘Still Alive’ After Hospital Stay
item.description: The 86-year-old pontiff spent three days undergoing treatment for bronchitis at a hospital in Rome.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis leaving the hospital in Rome on Saturday. The Vatican said he would take part in all of the Holy Week celebrations.

item.title: Security Force or Anti-Arab Militia? Israelis Feud Over Far-Right Plan
item.description: The far-right security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, wants to create a national guard that he would control, saying it is needed to guarantee Israel’s security.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Itamar Ben-Gvir in Jerusalem in October.

item.title: Gift of a Stethoscope to a Refugee Child Inspired a Career of Caring
item.description: Waheed Arian fled the war in Afghanistan when he was a teenager. Now an emergency room doctor in Britain, he has made it his mission to bring hope and healing to others.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waheed Arian, a doctor in Chester, England, was once an asylum seeker from Afghanistan.

item.title: Ukraine Charges a Leading Ukrainian Vicar, as Russia Pounds Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The charge against the religious leader, Pavlo Lebid, came as Russian forces hit the town of Avdiivka, among 70 other targets, along the front line.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Metropolitan Pavlo Lebid at the end of the morning service at the Pechersk Lavra on Thursday. Ukraine’s security service charged Mr. Lebid on Saturday with being in league with Russia and supporting Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Thailand’s Unemployed Elephants Are Back Home, Huge and Hungry
item.description: When the tourists who rode them disappeared from resort destinations, Thailand’s captive elephants, and their owners, went back to their birth villages, where finding enough food has been a struggle.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elephants are a common sight on the streets of Baan Ta Klang village, in Thailand. Here, a mahout rides his elephant past a sculpture of a mythical, multiheaded elephant in February.

item.title: For Ukrainian Convicts, a Strange Odyssey Through Russian Prisons
item.description: When Russian troops left Kherson, they took with them 2,500 Ukrainian convicts from local prisons. For some, it was the start of a bewildering, five-country journey highlighting the war’s absurdity.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ekaterina Bodyagina and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Fedorenko in his hometown, Pryluky, in Ukraine, last month. He had been in prison in Kherson when he was forcibly taken into Russian territory.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius, Olympian Convicted of Murder, Is Denied Parole
item.description: Mr. Pistorius, who has maintained that the killing was an accident and that he is remorseful, has served almost half of his 15-year sentence.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius in the high court in Pretoria, South Africa, in 2014.

item.title: French Anger at Macron Seeps Into Bordeaux
item.description: Even Bordeaux, known for its surrounding vineyards and conservative politics, has become a flashpoint. The City Hall’s charred doors attest to that.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Andrea Mantovani
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times

item.title: Sanna Marin, Finland’s Political Rock Star, Could Be Slipping
item.description: Parliamentary elections on Sunday are extremely tight among the three biggest parties, with the prime minister’s Social Democrats in a tough fight to lead the next government.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Geoffroy Van Der Hasselt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanna Marin of Finland in Brussels in December. Ahead of the election, the country’s three main parties are essentially tied in the polls.

item.title: Trump Indictment Is a First for the U.S. but Not for Other Nations
item.description: Scholars say it is important to hold the powerful legally accountable, but there are likely to be charges — well-founded or not — that prosecutors have political motives.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump in March. The United States has been an outlier in its reluctance to charge a former leader, until now.

item.title: As Israel’s Crises Pile Up, a Far-Right Minister Is a Common Thread
item.description: Bezalel Smotrich, the finance minister, is a longtime advocate of contentious plans to overhaul the judiciary. He has also exacerbated tensions with Palestinians and Israel’s allies.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Bezalel Smotrich, Israel’s finance minister, seated, in a meeting at the Parliament in Jerusalem this month.

item.title: In Arrest of US Reporter, Russia Doubles Down on Isolation From West
item.description: The Kremlin, which accused a Wall Street Journal correspondent of being a spy, made a move not seen since the Cold War, further raising the barriers between Russia and the West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media of President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday. The Kremlin left little doubt that Mr. Putin had personally approved the arrest of a Wall Street Journal journalist.

item.title: Green Savior or Deadly Menace? Paris Votes on E-Scooter Ban
item.description: For five years, the French capital has permitted the renting of electric scooters, which have proven both popular and perilous. On Sunday, voters will decide whether to end the experiment.
item.dc:creator: Tom Nouvian
item.media:description: Riding an electric scooter in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Bring the Kids Along
item.description: We take our children on vacation to expose them to history, novelty and beauty.
item.dc:creator: Amy Virshup

item.title: Far-Left Canadians Susceptible to Russian Influence Too
item.description: Researchers found that on Twitter, members of Canada’s far left joined those on the far right in embracing pro-Russian messages created by a two-year Russian influence campaign.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at the commemoration ceremony for Armistice Day, 100 years after the end of World War I, in Paris in 2018.

item.title: Why Is Finland the Happiest Country on Earth? The Answer Is Complicated.
item.description: The Nordic nation has been ranked the happiest country on earth for six consecutive years. But when you talk to individual Finns, the reality is a bit more complicated.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Colston and Jake Michaels
item.media:credit: Jake Michaels for The New York Times
item.media:description: Henna and Niklas Hukari, siblings who play badminton in the rural community of Toholampi, are among more than a dozen Finns we spoke with about how optimism manifests in their lives.

item.title: Inside Saudi Arabia’s Global Push for Nuclear Power
item.description: Despite qualms in Washington, Saudi officials have pressed the United States to help them develop nuclear power. But they are also exploring other options, including China.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Vivian Nereim and Kate Kelly
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Looking over Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Saudi officials are exploring options to work with countries other than the United States to develop a nuclear energy program.

item.title: Israeli Police Fatally Shoot Arab Outside Jerusalem Holy Site
item.description: The man was shot dead early Saturday at the edge of the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount. The circumstances of the killing were disputed and risked raising tensions during Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Crowds of worshipers outside the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, on Friday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Step Up Recruitment, Bracing for Fights Ahead
item.description: After a winter of intense battles and heavy losses in Ukraine’s east, both Russia and Ukraine are taking steps to replenish their depleted forces.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers monitor movements of Russian troops from their fortified position on the front line in Toretsk, eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Espionage Charge Adds Hurdle to Freeing a Reporter Detained in Russia
item.description: The Biden administration recently secured the release of two Americans convicted of criminal charges in Russia, but even fabricated charges of spying can raise the stakes.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: The Wall Street Journal, via Reuters
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, is accused by Russia of trying to gain illicit information about the country’s “military-industrial complex.”

item.title: Bodies of 8 Migrants Found in River Along U.S.-Canadian Border
item.description: The authorities were searching for more bodies in the St. Lawrence River of migrants believed to have been attempting to cross illegally into the United States.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Volunteers searching the marshland for bodies of missing migrants on Friday in Akwesasne, Quebec.

item.title: Putin Allies Must Decide Whether to Host a Wanted Man
item.description: The International Criminal Court’s arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin could thrust his allies into domestic and foreign legal disputes, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and John Eligon
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media of President Vladimir V. Putin at a Russia-Africa conference in Moscow in March. South Africa has faced particular scrutiny since the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Putin, because it may host him this summer.

item.title: What I’m Reading: Presidential Indictment Edition
item.description: Criminal cases against former leaders can be a positive sign about a country’s institutions. But of course politics often plays a role as well.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Times Square in Manhattan after the news broke on Thursday that a grand jury had voted to indict former President Donald Trump.

item.title: Now Playing in China: Putin-Aligned Artists Shunned in the West
item.description: As Russia works to shore up its image and rebuild its soft power after its invasion of Ukraine, it is strengthening cultural ties with friendly nations, including China.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: via National Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: The Russian maestro Valery Gergiev, who has been shunned by the West, conducted the Mariinsky Orchestra in Beijing.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich, WSJ Reporter Detained in Russia, Likely to Spend Months in Prison
item.description: Russia detained Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, and accused him of espionage. The Journal and U.S. officials have vehemently denied the allegation.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Lefortovo, a high-security prison in Moscow where the American reporter Evan Gershkovich is reportedly being held on espionage charges.

item.title: Belarus, Echoing Russia, Raises Prospect of Nuclear Conflict
item.description: Because of the conflict in Ukraine, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus said, “a third world war loomed on the horizon with nuclear fires.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Belarusian Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by the Belarusian Presidential Press Service shows President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko delivering a state-of-the nation address in Minsk, Belarus, on Friday.

item.title: In Finland, Leaders Celebrate NATO Membership Progress
item.description: Finland’s president, Sauli Niinistö, said his country would “be a strong and capable ally, committed to the security of the alliance.”
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola, Victoria Kim and Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Turkish lawmakers voting on Finland’s bid to join NATO in Ankara, the capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Is Expected to Be Released From the Hospital on Saturday
item.description: Francis, who has been coping with a variety of health issues, was taken to the hospital on Wednesday. He is being treated with antibiotics for bronchitis, according to the Vatican.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis met with children during his weekly general audience in St. Peter’s Square on Wednesday before he was taken to the hospital.

item.title: Donald Trump Indicted
item.description: He is the first former U.S. president to face criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump.

item.title: In a Land With No Soccer, Group Hopes to Use It to Score Climate Goals
item.description: The Marshall Islands Soccer Federation aims to draw interest in the sport — and to growing global warming events in the Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Marshall Islands’ delegation at the opening ceremony of the Tokyo Olympics in 2021.

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Falls to 6.9%, as Energy Prices Ease
item.description: The rate of inflation in countries using the euro slipped to 6.9 percent over the year through March, from 8.5 percent the previous month, but underlying price gains edged higher.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: With its arrest of an American reporter, Russia doubles down on isolation.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media of President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday. The Kremlin left little doubt that Mr. Putin had personally approved the arrest of a Wall Street Journal journalist.

item.title: In Taiwan’s Waters, a Hunt for Tiny, Wriggling ‘Gold’
item.description: For generations, people have fished for baby eels in the island’s estuaries. But they seem to be getting harder to find.
item.dc:creator: Lam Yik Fei, Amy Chang Chien and Tiffany May
item.media:description: Fishing for glass eels along the Lanyang River in Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump was indicted.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Donald Trump has created an aura of legal invincibility that the indictment threatens to puncture.

item.title: Turkey Approves Finland’s NATO Membership, a Defeat for Putin
item.description: Finland’s entry into the military alliance after Turkey formally signed off is a significant defeat for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Sauli Niinisto of Finland and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey met in Ankara earlier this month.

item.title: In Berlin, King Charles Lauds Germany’s Support for Ukraine
item.description: “Together we must be vigilant against threats to our values,” the British monarch said to German lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III of Britain, front center, after delivering a speech at the Bundestag in Berlin on Thursday.

item.title: Five Arrested in Migration Center Fire That Left 39 Dead in Mexico
item.description: The authorities said arrest warrants had been obtained for three government migration officials, two private security workers and a migrant accused of starting the blaze.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asylum-seeking migrants, mostly from Venezuela, crossing the Rio Grande into the United States on Wednesday, two days after at least 39 migrants died in a fire at a detention center in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.

item.title: 6 U.S. Service Members Suffered Traumatic Brain Injuries in Syria Attacks
item.description: The Pentagon said the injuries were diagnosed during routine screenings in the days after the strikes by Iranian-backed militants.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Brig. Gen. Patrick S. Ryder, the Pentagon spokesman, said eight militants were killed in a retaliatory U.S. airstrike in Syria last week.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Trump Indicted
item.description: Also, an American journalist arrested in Russia and a Chinese billionaire’s downfall.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Kreutter
item.media:description: The indictment kicks off a new and volatile phase in Donald Trump’s post-presidential life.

item.title: Days After Netanyahu Fired Him, Israel’s Defense Minister Is Still on the Job
item.description: Yoav Gallant, Israel’s defense minister, was fired on Sunday, setting off unrest, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu never formally confirmed his dismissal.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant, the Israeli defense minister, was fired on Sunday but has remained in his post because he did not receive a notification letter.

item.title: Kushner Firm Got Hundreds of Millions From 2 Persian Gulf Nations
item.description: The infusion of money from interests in the two Persian Gulf monarchies reflects the close ties to Middle Eastern countries established by Jared Kushner, former President Donald Trump’s son-in-law.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Swan, Kate Kelly, Maggie Haberman and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Kushner attending the Future Investment Initiative conference in Saudi Arabia last year. Mr. Kushner’s private equity firm has received investments from Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: At Least 35 Are Killed in India When a Temple’s Well Cover Collapses
item.description: Rescuers struggled to reach other Hindu worshipers who were trapped and injured in a packed temple in Indore during a religious festival.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: An accident victim was carried toward an ambulance at the site of the disaster on Thursday in Indore, India.

item.title: Vatican Repudiates ‘Doctrine of Discovery,’ Used as Justification for Colonization
item.description: Indigenous communities have long called on the Vatican rescind the concept, which had been used over the centuries to seize land from people in the Americas, Africa and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Conference of Catholic Bishops
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis meeting with Indigenous leaders during his trip in Canada, last year.

item.title: U.S. Puts Sanctions on Man Accused of Working on Russia-North Korea Arms Deal
item.description: A White House spokesman said the man would be in violation of several U.N. Security Council resolutions.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers

item.title: Macron, Trying to Move Past Pension Fury, Announces Water Plan
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France presented conservation proposals after an exceptionally dry winter. But his government is still dogged by pension protests.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Savines-le-Lac on Thursday.

item.title: Bankers Are Convicted of Allowing a Putin Ally to Deposit Millions in Swiss Accounts
item.description: The accounts were opened in the name of Sergei P. Roldugin, a concert cellist nicknamed “Putin’s wallet.”
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Outside a court in Zurich this month during the Gazprombank case.

item.title: A.I., Brain Scans and Cameras: The Spread of Police Surveillance Tech
item.description: In the Middle East, artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies have become part of everyday policing.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Dubai’s police run next-generation surveillance systems from a headquarters north of the city’s downtown skyscrapers and malls.

item.title: Police Missteps Contributed to Canada’s Deadliest Shooting Rampage, Inquiry Says
item.description: A commission found there was confusion, poor communication and inflexible thinking among the police during a 13-hour rampage in 2020 in which 23 people died.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Andrew Vaughan/The Canadian Press via AP
item.media:description: A memorial service for an officer killed in the line of duty during a mass shooting in April 2020 in rural Nova Scotia. A commission investigating the killings found a litany of missteps that contributed to the death toll.

item.title: Studies Link Common Childhood Viruses to Rare Hepatitis Cases
item.description: Infection with multiple common viruses may be responsible for the cases that puzzled doctors last year.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Why This Colombian Town Still Celebrates Christmas in February
item.description: The Afro-Colombian residents of Quinamayó have followed a unique tradition: celebrating Christmas 40 days after the traditional date, a custom begun under the subjugation of slavery.
item.dc:creator: Jaír F. Coll and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Dancing during Christmas celebrations in Quinamayó, Colombia, last month.

item.title: Sailboat Crew Rescued After Hitting Whale in Pacific Ocean
item.description: After the collision in the Pacific Ocean this month, Rick Rodriguez and three other sailors were rescued by a fellow boater, with an assist from a satellite internet signal.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Pope ‘Gradually Improving’ After First Night in the Hospital
item.description: Few details were available about the condition of Pope Francis, 86, and it was too early to determine whether he would be able to attend several Easter-related ceremonies.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Pope Francis was helped to a car after a weekly audience in St. Peter’s Square on Wednesday. He was later taken to a hospital for treatment for a respiratory infection, the Vatican said.

item.title: Bolsonaro Returns to Brazil, Ending Self-Imposed Exile
item.description: The former president returned to a tense political landscape in which he is under investigation for spreading election misinformation and for inspiring the Jan. 8 attack in the capital.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, the former president of Brazil, waving to supporters outside the Liberal Party’s headquarters in Brasília on Thursday.

item.title: A Mexican Grandmother Finds the Right Recipe for Culinary Stardom
item.description: Through her YouTube videos, Doña Ángela has become among the most watched and beloved cooks in the crowded market of online food shows. But what explains her widespread popularity?
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.category: De Mi Rancho a Tu Cocina (YouTube Channel)
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bradley Coss and his mother, Cruz Ortiz, watch Doña Ángela’s YouTube cooking videos from their home in El Paso. “You can see in my mom the genuine joy it brings her to watch those videos.” Mr. Coss said.

item.title: The Biggest Battle in Ukraine
item.description: Why Russia and Ukraine are fighting for a city with little strategic value.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Ukrainian military on the street of Bakhmut in December 2022.

item.title: Under the Taliban, Afghanistan Is Trying to Make Due With Less
item.description: In a time of famine and money shortages, meals are a rallying point — and a topic of worry — during a season of change in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amanullah, the pulao master at a popular restaurant in Kabul, preparing to serve the morning’s first customers last month. Since the Taliban took over, what people eat has changed.

item.title: Ukraine Goes Dark: NASA Images Drive Home a Nation’s Anguish
item.description: A satellite operated by NASA and NOAA bares how Russia’s drones and missiles knocked out the nation’s power.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad, Sarah Kerr, Marc Santora and Tim Wallace
item.media:credit: NASA Black Marble Team, Goddard Space Flight Center

item.title: Ukrainians in a Hidden Command Post See Bakhmut Going Their Way
item.description: Ukrainian commanders said that Russia exhausted all its reserves on the eastern city, though soldiers said the cost in lives had been steep.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: The military operations of a major Ukrainian battle group defending the city of Bakhmut from an unnamed location in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Russia Detains Wall Street Journal Reporter, Accusing Him of Espionage
item.description: The newspaper said it “vehemently denies the allegations” against Evan Gershkovich, an American, and the White House called his detention “unacceptable.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Mr. Gershkovich has worked for The Journal in Moscow since January 2022.
